newsitem.title: TURKMENISTAN: Bateman, Turkmens sign gas pipeline deal.
newsitem.headline: Bateman, Turkmens sign gas pipeline deal.

text.p: Turkmenistan and a Dutch subsidiary of Johannesburg-based Bateman Project Holdings Ltd signed a $180 million deal to reconstruct Tukmenistan's gas infrastructure, a government official said on Thursday.
He said the first stage of the reconstruction would be on the Central Asia-Centre gas pipeline, Turkmenistan's only export outlet which transports natural gas to Europe via Russia's pipeline system.
This would involve building a new compressor station on Turkmenistan's border with northern neighbour Uzbekistan, the official said.
Bateman said it has attracted sufficient funds from sources in the United States and South Africa to finance the project.
It said Turkish company Gama will carry out the reconstruction work, while Israel's Merhav would control the financing of the project.
"We take overall responsibility for the implementation of the project," a Bateman spokesman said from Johannesburg.
The Turkmen official said Turkmenistan plans to boost natural gas exports to 40 billion cubic metres (bcm) in 1997 from 24 bcm last year.
Of this year's planned exports, 20 bcm is expected to go to Western European consumers, in line with the quota agreed between Turkmenistan and Russia's gas monopoly RAO Gazprom last year.
Last November Gazprom agreed to supply gas from Turkmenistan to Ukraine and Western Europe through Russian pipelines.
The priority for Turkmenistan's hard-hit economy is to export gas to Western European hard-currency markets.
Turkmenistan is building a new one to southern neighbour Iran, and there are also plans to build an export pipeline to Pakistan via war-torn Afghanistan.
The desert nation of four million people has seen gas production plunge to 35.18 bcm last year from 63.5 bcm in 1993. Production is officially targeted at 44 bcm in 1997.
